newsitem.title: GERMANY: Koebnick sees no near-term change in German rates.
newsitem.headline: Koebnick sees no near-term change in German rates.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Hans-Juergen Koebnick on Wednesday ruled out any near-term change in German interest rates but said that the Bundesbank would continue to monitor conditions.
If room existed the Bundesbank could possibly consider taking action to change its policy, he told reporters.
Bundesbank president Hans Tietmeyer made clear after the Bundesbank's last policy easing on August 22 that markets should not expect any further moves for some time.
Koebnick said he expected growth in M3 money supply to continue growing although he declined to give any specific forecasts on August data expected in the next few days.
But he did say there was a possibility that M3 could gradually edge back into the upper range of the four to seven percent corridor set for 1996 M3 growth.
Recently, Bundesbank officials have said that if M3 growth slowed considerably, there could be room to nudge the repo rate, currently set at 3.00 percent, still lower.
Koebnick was speaking on the sidelines of a banking event in Merzig at which he earlier held a speech.
